title: Reflection - smooth reflecting sphere and 3 rays

content.question: A sphere has a smooth surface from which incident light rays are reflected. Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> shows the sphere and three incident rays, rays <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, along with a pair of <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate axes with its origin at the center of the sphere. Rays <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are each parallel to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis, and Ray <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is directed at <math alttext="45 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>45</mn><mo>°</mo></math> to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis as shown. Which of the following ranks the angles <math alttext="theta sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="theta sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="theta sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> between each reflected ray and the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction for rays <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, respectively? The angle between a reflected ray and the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction is defined as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> for two rays.

choices.label: <math alttext="theta sub 1 equals theta sub 2, which equals theta sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="open parenthesis, theta sub 1 equals theta sub 2, close parenthesis, which is greater than theta sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>></mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="theta sub 1 is greater than theta sub 2, which is greater than theta sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="theta sub 2 is greater than theta sub 3, which is greater than theta sub 1 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="open parenthesis, theta sub 1 equals theta sub 2, close parenthesis, which is greater than theta sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>></mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>
